Part 1 of the Extradition Act 2003 (extradition to category 1 territories) is amended as follows.
In section 11 (bars to extradition)—

P3para.Text: at the end of subsection (1) insert—
forum.
after subsection (1) insert—

P2para.Text: But the judge is to decide whether the person’s extradition is barred by reason of forum only in a case where the Part 1 warrant contains the statement referred to in section 2(3) (warrant issued for purposes of prosecution for offence in category 1 territory).

P3para.Text: in subsection (2), for the words from “12” to “apply” substitute “12 to 19F apply”.

P1para.Text: After section 19A insert—

P2para.Text: The extradition of a person (“D”) to a category 1 territory is barred by reason of forum if the extradition would not be in the interests of justice.
For the purposes of this section, the extradition would not be in the interests of justice if the judge—

P3para.Text: decides that a substantial measure of D’s relevant activity was performed in the United Kingdom; and
decides, having regard to the specified matters relating to the interests of justice (and only those matters), that the extradition should not take place.

P2para.Text: These are the specified matters relating to the interests of justice—

P3para.Text: the place where most of the loss or harm resulting from the extradition offence occurred or was intended to occur;
the interests of any victims of the extradition offence;

any belief of a prosecutor that the United Kingdom, or a particular part of the United Kingdom, is not an appropriate jurisdiction in which to prosecute D in respect of the conduct constituting the extradition offence;

were D to be prosecuted in a part of the United Kingdom for an offence that corresponds to the extradition offence, whether evidence necessary to prove the offence is or could be made available in the United Kingdom;
the desirability and practicability of all prosecutions relating to the extradition offence taking place in one jurisdiction, having regard (in particular) to—

P4para.Text: the jurisdictions in which witnesses, co-defendants and other suspects are located, and
the practicability of the evidence of such persons being given in the United Kingdom or in jurisdictions outside the United Kingdom;

P3para.Text: D’s connections with the United Kingdom.

P2para.Text: In deciding whether the extradition would not be in the interests of justice, the judge must have regard to the desirability of not requiring the disclosure of material which is subject to restrictions on disclosure in the category 1 territory concerned.

If, on an application by a prosecutor, it appears to the judge that the prosecutor has considered the offences for which D could be prosecuted in the United Kingdom, or a part of the United Kingdom, in respect of the conduct constituting the extradition offence, the judge must make that prosecutor a party to the proceedings on the question of whether D’s extradition is barred by reason of forum.
In this section “D’s relevant activity” means activity which is material to the commission of the extradition offence and which is alleged to have been performed by D.

P1group.Title: Effect of prosecutor’s certificates on forum proceedings

P2para.Text: The judge hearing proceedings under section 19B (the “forum proceedings”) must decide that the extradition is not barred by reason of forum if (at a time when the judge has not yet decided the proceedings) the judge receives a prosecutor’s certificate relating to the extradition.
That duty to decide the forum proceedings in that way is subject to the determination of any question relating to the prosecutor’s certificate raised in accordance with section 19E.
A designated prosecutor may apply for the forum proceedings to be adjourned for the purpose of assisting that or any other designated prosecutor—

P3para.Text: in considering whether to give a prosecutor’s certificate relating to the extradition,
in giving such a certificate, or
in sending such a certificate to the judge.

P2para.Text: If such an application is made, the judge must—

P3para.Text: adjourn the forum proceedings until the application is decided; and
continue the adjournment, for such period as appears to the judge to be reasonable, if the application is granted.

P2para.Text: But the judge must end the adjournment if the application is not granted.
A “prosecutor’s certificate” is a certificate given by a designated prosecutor which—

P3para.Text: certifies both matter A and matter B, and
certifies either matter C or matter D.

P2para.Text: Matter A is that a responsible prosecutor has considered the offences for which D could be prosecuted in the United Kingdom, or a part of the United Kingdom, in respect of the conduct constituting the extradition offence.
Matter B is that the responsible prosecutor has decided that there are one or more such offences that correspond to the extradition offence (the “corresponding offences”).
Matter C is that—

P3para.Text: the responsible prosecutor has made a formal decision as to the prosecution of D for the corresponding offences,
that decision is that D should not be prosecuted for the corresponding offences, and
the reason for that decision is a belief that—

P4para.Text: there would be insufficient admissible evidence for the prosecution; or
the prosecution would not be in the public interest.

P2para.Text: Matter D is that the responsible prosecutor believes that D should not be prosecuted for the corresponding offences because there are concerns about the disclosure of sensitive material in—

P3para.Text: the prosecution of D for the corresponding offences, or
any other proceedings.

P2para.Text: In relation to the extradition of any person to a category 1 territory, neither this section nor any other rule of law (whether or not contained in an enactment) may require a designated prosecutor—

P3para.Text: to consider any matter relevant to giving a prosecutor’s certificate; or
to consider whether to give a prosecutor’s certificate.

P2para.Text: In this section “sensitive material” means material which appears to the responsible prosecutor to be sensitive, including material appearing to be sensitive on grounds relating to—

P3para.Text: national security,
international relations, or

the prevention or detection of crime (including grounds relating to the identification or activities of witnesses, informants or any other persons supplying information to the police or any other law enforcement agency who may be in danger if their identities are revealed).

P2para.Text: No decision of a designated prosecutor relating to a prosecutor’s certificate in respect of D’s extradition (a “relevant certification decision”) may be questioned except on an appeal under section 26 against an order for that extradition.
For the purpose of—

P3para.Text: determining whether to give permission for a relevant certification decision to be questioned, and
determining any such question (if that permission is given),

P2para.Text: the High Court must apply the procedures and principles which would be applied by it on an application for judicial review.
In a case where the High Court quashes a prosecutor’s certificate, the High Court is to decide the question of whether or not the extradition is barred by reason of forum.
Where the High Court is required to decide that question by virtue of subsection (3)—

P3para.Text: sections 19B to 19D and this section apply in relation to that decision (with the appropriate modifications) as they apply to a decision by a judge; and
in particular—

P4para.Text: a reference in this section to an appeal under section 26 has effect as a reference to an appeal under section 32 to the Supreme Court;
a reference in this section to the High Court has effect as a reference to the Supreme Court.

These expressions have the meanings given—

a member of the Crown Prosecution Service, or
any other person who—
is a prosecutor designated for the purposes of this section by order made by the Secretary of State, or
is within a description of prosecutors so designated;

England and Wales;

the designated prosecutor giving the certificate, or
another designated prosecutor.

A reference to a formal decision as to the prosecution of D for an offence is a reference to a decision (made after complying with, in particular, any applicable requirement concerning a code of practice) that D should, or should not, be prosecuted for the offence.

P2para.Text: The extradition of a person (“D”) to a category 2 territory is barred by reason of forum if the extradition would not be in the interests of justice.
For the purposes of this section, the extradition would not be in the interests of justice if the judge—

P3para.Text: decides that a substantial measure of D’s relevant activity was performed in the United Kingdom; and
decides, having regard to the specified matters relating to the interests of justice (and only those matters), that the extradition should not take place.

P2para.Text: These are the specified matters relating to the interests of justice—

P3para.Text: the place where most of the loss or harm resulting from the extradition offence occurred or was intended to occur;
the interests of any victims of the extradition offence;

any belief of a prosecutor that the United Kingdom, or a particular part of the United Kingdom, is not an appropriate jurisdiction in which to prosecute D in respect of the conduct constituting the extradition offence;
were D to be prosecuted in a part of the United Kingdom for an offence that corresponds to the extradition offence,
whether evidence necessary to prove the offence is or could be made available in the United Kingdom;
the desirability and practicability of all prosecutions relating to the extradition offence taking place in one jurisdiction, having regard (in particular) to—

P4para.Text: the jurisdictions in which witnesses, co-defendants and other suspects are located, and
the practicability of the evidence of such persons being given in the United Kingdom or in jurisdictions outside the United Kingdom;

P3para.Text: D’s connections with the United Kingdom.

P2para.Text: In deciding whether the extradition would not be in the interests of justice, the judge must have regard to the desirability of not requiring the disclosure of material which is subject to restrictions on disclosure in the category 2 territory concerned.

If, on an application by a prosecutor, it appears to the judge that the prosecutor has considered the offences for which D could be prosecuted in the United Kingdom, or a part of the United Kingdom, in respect of the conduct constituting the extradition offence, the judge must make that prosecutor a party to the proceedings on the question of whether D’s extradition is barred by reason of forum.
In this section “D’s relevant activity” means activity which is material to the commission of the extradition offence and is alleged to have been performed by D.

P2para.Text: This section applies if immediately after the judge orders the person’s discharge the judge is informed by the authority which issued the Part 1 warrant (“the issuing authority”) that it intends to appeal under section 28 (“the High Court appeal”).

P3para.Text: when the proceedings on the appeal are abandoned;
when the High Court—

P4para.Text: allows the appeal, or
dismisses the appeal.

P3para.Text: the High Court appeal is dismissed, and

immediately after dismissing it, the High Court is informed by the issuing authority that it intends to bring an appeal to the Supreme Court against a determination of a relevant devolution issue (“the Supreme Court appeal”),

P2para.Text: the High Court must remand the person in custody or on bail while the Supreme Court appeal is pending.

P3para.Text: the end of the period of 28 days starting with the day when the High Court appeal is dismissed (unless, within that period, an application is made to the High Court for permission to make the Supreme Court appeal);

the end of the period of 28 days starting with the day on which permission is given to bring the Supreme Court appeal (unless the appeal is brought within that period);
the time when the proceedings on the Supreme Court appeal are abandoned;
the time when there is no further step that can be taken in relation to the Supreme Court appeal by the issuing authority (ignoring any power of a court to grant leave to take a step out of time).

P2para.Text: Subsection (1) does not prevent an appeal against a determination of a devolution issue.

In section 118 (extradition following appeal), for subsection (8) substitute—
The preceding provisions of this section do not apply to Scotland.
After that section insert—
This section applies if—

P3para.Text: there is an appeal to the High Court under section 103, 108 or 110 against a decision or order relating to a person’s extradition to a category 2 territory, and
the effect of the decision in the relevant proceedings is that the person must be extradited to the category 2 territory.

P2para.Text: The “relevant proceedings” are—

P3para.Text: the proceedings on the appeal under section 103, 108 or 110 if—

P4para.Text: no Supreme Court devolution appeal is made, or
a Supreme Court devolution appeal is made and the Supreme Court remits the case to the High Court, or

P3para.Text: the proceedings on a Supreme Court devolution appeal if such an appeal is made and the Supreme Court does not remit the case to the High Court.

P2para.Text: The person must be extradited to the category 2 territory before the end of the required period, which is 28 days starting with—

P3para.Text: the day on which the decision in the relevant proceedings becomes final, or
the day on which the relevant proceedings are abandoned.

P2para.Text: In a case where the relevant proceedings are proceedings on the appeal under section 103, 108 or 110 (except the case has been remitted to the High Court on a Supreme Court devolution appeal), the decision in those proceedings becomes final—

P3para.Text: at the end of the period of 28 days starting with the day of the High Court’s decision on the appeal (unless, within that period, an application is made to the High Court for permission to make a Supreme Court devolution appeal);

at the end of the period of 28 days starting with the day when the High Court refuses permission to make a Supreme Court devolution appeal (unless, within that period, an application is made to the Supreme Court for permission to make the appeal);
when the Supreme Court refuses permission to make a Supreme Court devolution appeal;

at the end of the permitted period, which is 28 days starting with the day on which permission to make a Supreme Court devolution appeal is granted, if no such appeal is brought before the end of that period.

P2para.Text: These must be ignored for the purposes of subsection (4)—

P3para.Text: any power of a court to extend the period permitted for applying for permission to appeal;
any power of a court to grant permission to take a step out of time.

P2para.Text: In a case where—

P3para.Text: the relevant proceedings are proceedings on the appeal under section 103, 108 or 110, and
the case has been remitted to the High Court on a Supreme Court devolution appeal,

P2para.Text: the decision in those proceedings becomes final when it is made.
In a case where—

P3para.Text: the relevant proceedings are proceedings on a Supreme Court devolution appeal, and
the decision is not to remit the case to the High Court,

P2para.Text: the decision in those proceedings becomes final when it is made.
If subsection (3) is not complied with and the person applies to the appropriate judge to be discharged, the judge must order the person’s discharge, unless reasonable cause is shown for the delay.
In this section “Supreme Court devolution appeal” means an appeal to the Supreme Court against a determination of a devolution issue relating to a person’s extradition.
This section applies only to Scotland.

P1para.Text: After section 118A (inserted by paragraph 27) insert—

P1group.Title: Scottish devolution issue: remand in custody or on bail

P2para.Text: This section applies where, on an appeal to the Supreme Court against a determination of a devolution issue relating to a person’s extradition under this Part, the Supreme Court—

P3para.Text: remits the case to the High Court, or
orders the person’s extradition.

P2para.Text: The Supreme Court must remand the person in custody or on bail pending the person’s extradition.
If the Supreme Court remands the person in custody, the High Court may later grant bail.

P1para.Text: In section 192 (general interpretation of Act), in the definition of “prescribed” in subsection (1), before “means” insert “(except in section 5A)”.
The amendments in paragraphs 3 to 6 do not affect the application of sections 83 and 96 of the Railways and Transport Safety Act 2003.
The Road Traffic Offenders Act 1988 is amended as follows.

P2para.Text: Section 15 (use of specimens in proceedings for an offence under section 3A, 4 or 5 of the Road Traffic Act) is amended as follows.
In the sidenote, for “section 4 or 5” substitute “any of sections 3A to 5A”.
In subsection (1), for “section 3A, 4 or 5” substitute “any of sections 3A to 5A”.
In subsection (2), for the words from “and, subject to” to the end substitute “and—

P3para.Text: it is to be assumed, subject to subsection (3) below, that the proportion of alcohol in the accused’s breath, blood or urine at the time of the alleged offence was not less than in the specimen;
it is to be assumed, subject to subsection (3A) below, that the proportion of a drug in the accused’s blood or urine at the time of the alleged offence was not less than in the specimen.

P2para.Text: In subsection (3), for “That assumption” substitute “The assumption in subsection (2)(a) above”.
After subsection (3) insert—
The assumption in subsection (2)(b) above is not to be made if the accused proves—

P3para.Text: that he took the drug before he provided the specimen or had the specimen taken from him and—

P4para.Text: in relation to an offence under section 3A, after the time of the alleged offence, and
otherwise, after he had ceased to drive, attempt to drive or be in charge of a vehicle on a road or other public place, and

P3para.Text: that had he not done so the proportion of the drug in his blood or urine—

P4para.Text: in the case of a specified controlled drug, would not have exceeded the specified limit for that drug, and
if it is alleged that he was unfit to drive through drugs, would not have been such as to impair his ability to drive properly.

P2para.Text: Section 24 (alternative verdicts: general) is amended as follows.
In the table in subsection (1), after the entry relating to section 5(1)(a) of the Road Traffic Act 1988 insert—

tr.td: Section 5A(1)(a) and (2) (driving or attempting to drive with concentration of specified controlled drug above specified limit)
Section 5A(1)(b) and (2) (being in charge of a vehicle with concentration of specified controlled drug above specified limit)

P2para.Text: In subsection (3), for “or 5(1)(a)” substitute “, 5(1)(a) or 5A(1)(a) and (2)”.

P1para.Text: In section 34 (disqualification for certain offences), in subsection (3), after paragraph (b) insert—

P3para.Text: section 5A(1)(a) and (2) (driving or attempting to drive with concentration of specified controlled drug above specified limit),

P1para.Text: In Schedule 1 (offences to which sections 1, 6, 11 and 12(1) apply), in the table, after the entry beginning “RTA section 5” insert—

tr.td: Driving or attempting to drive, or being in charge of a motor vehicle, with concentration of specified controlled drug above specified limit.

P1para.Text: The amendments in paragraph 10 do not affect the application of sections 83 and 96 of the Railways and Transport Safety Act 2003.
In Schedule 1 to the Football Spectators Act 1989 (relevant offences for purposes of making banning order), in paragraph 1(l)—

P3para.Text: for “or 5” substitute “, 5 or 5A”;
after “limit” insert “or with a concentration of a specified controlled drug above the specified limit”.

P1para.Text: In Schedule 3 to the Crime (International Co-operation) Act 2003 (offences notifiable to authority of member State where offender normally resident), in Part 1 (offences where no minimum period of disqualification necessary), after paragraph (f) of paragraph 3 insert—

P3para.Text: section 5A (driving, or being in charge, of a motor vehicle with concentration of specified controlled drug above specified limit),

P1para.Text: In Schedule 1 to the Armed Forces Act 2006 (criminal conduct offences that may be dealt with at a summary hearing), in Part 1 (offences that may be dealt with without permission), after paragraph 9 insert—
An offence under section 5A of that Act (driving a vehicle with concentration of specified controlled drug above specified limit).

If the Secretary of State is proposing to make an order under section 2, the Secretary of State must consult those persons whom the Secretary of State considers would be affected by the proposed order.

P2para.Text: If, after such a consultation, the Secretary of State considers it appropriate to proceed with the making of the order, the Secretary of State must lay before Parliament—

P3para.Text: a draft order, and
a document which explains the order.

P2para.Text: The Secretary of State may not act under this paragraph before the end of the period of twelve weeks beginning with the day on which the consultation began.

The Secretary of State may make an order in the terms of the draft order laid under paragraph 2 if, after the expiry of the 40-day period, the draft order is approved by a resolution of each House of Parliament.
But the procedure in paragraph 4 is to apply to the draft order instead of the procedure in this paragraph if—

P3para.Text: either House of Parliament so resolves within the 30-day period, or

a committee of either House charged with reporting on the draft order so recommends within the 30-day period and the House to which the recommendation is made does not by resolution reject the recommendation within that period.

P2para.Text: The Secretary of State must have regard to—

P3para.Text: any representations,
any resolution of either House of Parliament, and
any recommendations of a committee of either House of Parliament charged with reporting on the draft order,

P2para.Text: made during the 60-day period with regard to the draft order.
If after the expiry of the 60-day period the draft order is approved by a resolution of each House of Parliament, the Secretary of State may make an order in the terms of the draft order.
If after the expiry of the 60-day period the Secretary of State wishes to proceed with the draft order but with material changes, the Secretary of State may lay before Parliament—

P3para.Text: a revised draft order, and
a statement giving a summary of the changes proposed.

P2para.Text: If the revised draft order is approved by a resolution of each House of Parliament, the Secretary of State may make an order in the terms of the revised draft order.
For the purposes of this paragraph an order is made in the terms of a draft order or revised draft order if it contains no material changes to its provisions.

In this Schedule, references to the “30-day”, “40-day” and “60-day” periods in relation to any draft order are to the periods of 30, 40 and 60 days beginning with the day on which the draft order was laid before Parliament.
For that purpose no account is to be taken of any time during which Parliament is dissolved or prorogued or during which either House is adjourned for more than four days.
